revisionDesc.p: Convert the Westminster Leningrad Codex files from TEI markup to OSIS book files.

work.title: BHS unaccented with Strongs
work.description: Unaccented Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia Hebrew with Strong's numbers by Rev. Graham.

work.title: A Concise Dictionary of the Words in the Hebrew Bible
with their Renderings in the King James Version
work.creator: James Strong, LL.D., S.T.D.
work.description: The data came from several PD sources which were full of errors. I cleaned them by comparing them to each other and (where necessary) looking at the original.
work.source: The exhaustive concordance of the Bible:

verse.note: We read or understand the cantillation in L differently than BHS (1983 Edition). Often this notation indicates a typographical error in BHS.

We read one or more consonants, vowels or punctuation (Maqqef, Dagesh or Mappiq) in L differently from BHS (1997). This is similar to the note ']c', but the latter refers to the accents. The older note ']3' encompasses the new uses of ']c', ']p' and ']t'.

We read one or more consonants, vowels or punctuation (Maqqef, Dagesh or Mappiq) in L differently from BHS (1997). This is similar to the note ']c', but the latter refers to the accents. The older note ']3' encompasses the new uses of ']c', ']p' and ']t'.
BHS has been faithful to the Leningrad Codex where there might be a question of the validity of the form and we keep the same form as BHS.
We read or understand the cantillation in L differently than BHS (1983 Edition). Often this notation indicates a typographical error in BHS.

We have abandoned or added a ketib/qere relative to BHS. In doing this we agree with L against BHS.

Puncta Extraordaria -- a \u05c4 is used to mark such marks in the text when they are above the line and a \u05c5 when they are below the line.
